column1: Kolding (Danish pronunciation: [ˈkʰʌle̝ŋ]) is a Danish seaport located at the head of Kolding Fjord in the Region of Southern Denmark. It is the seat of Kolding Municipality. It is a transportation
column5: principally geared towards shipbuilding. The manufacturing of machinery and textiles and livestock export are other economically significant activities.

column1: == History ==
In the Battle of Kolding
column3: the allied Polish and Danish forces under hetman Stefan Czarniecki defeated the Swedish forces of Charles X Gustav of Sweden.

column1: A battle between German and Danish forces took place near the town on 23 April 1849 during the First War of Schleswig.
On 3 November 2004
column2: the N. P. Johnsen's Fireworks Factory in the suburb of Seest exploded. One firefighter died
column4: and around 2000 people were evacuated and some of them lost their homes during this disaster in this suburb of Kolding.

column1: == Overview ==
Located in Kolding is the former royal castle of Koldinghus. This was built in the 13th century by King Eric Klipping and is now a museum with certain parts of the castle
column3: being used for governmental ceremonial events. It was the last royal residence in Jutland. Another notable site is the 13th century stone Church of Saint Nicholas (Danish: Sankt Nicolai)
column4: which is one of the oldest in Denmark. Popular tourist attractions include the Trapholt art museum and the gardens Geografisk Have. Trapholt holds collections of Danish arts from 1900 onwards and a smaller number of non-Danish exhibits. Kolding is also the site of Designskolen Kolding

column1: === Main sights ===
The municipal museum
column3: is located in the castle and former royal palace. It has a collection of Danish art from the late Middle Ages to the 1940s
column5: and an extensive collection of items in gold and silver.

column1: The Trapholt art museum features many pieces from mainly Danish artists
column2: along with a large collection of chairs.

column1: Also Kolding houses the Danish Museum of Nurses (Danish: Dansk Sygeplejemuseum) which is situated in the former reception building of the former tuberculosis sanatorium for children. The exhibition also include this past of the buildings. The main part of the sanatorium is now a hotel
column2: situated in a minor forest and overlooking the water. The building itself is very beautiful and built to resemble a palace.

column1: == Education ==
A branch of University College South (Danish: University College Syd) can be found in Kolding.
A branch campus of University of Southern Denmark (Danish: Syddansk Universitet) is located in the former hospital which was closed in 1975. Further
column2: the new Campus Kolding opened downtown in 2014. The city is also home to Design School Kolding (Designskolen Kolding)
column3: established in 1967 and teaching undergraduate and postgraduate degrees in the areas of fashion
column4: graphic design and textiles.The new building of University of Southern Denmark will be built further to the east at Grønborggrunden in central Kolding.
